title: Can smart-watches detect if the person who is wearing it is sleeping? If yes, how? - Quora

response.answer_text: YES!Smart watches can detect if the person wearing it is asleep. I don't think that there is currently an app for it but the tiny sensors that are being used by the mobile industry can indeed help to conclude if a person is sleeping or not. Accelerometer-As its name implies, it measures the acceleration that the sensor is experiencing relative to freefall.If we move it in anydirection and data from this sensor will spike, but leave it still and it will go flat. Data from this sensor can be an important factor to determine if the person is asleep. Gyroscope-The gyroscope is a sensor that can provide orientation information as well, but with greater precision. Heart rate monitor-Debuted with the Samsung Galaxy S5, this sensor can detect the heart rate of the person and the data from this sensor can play a major role in determining if the person is asleep. Light sensor-It is a sensor that measures how brightthe ambient light is. The device's software uses thisdata to adjust the display's brightness automatically. And as we know, people normally sleep with little or no light in their rooms, the data from this sensor can also be useful.

It has a number of sensors that can monitor your heart rate, and in particular movement. However despite a lot of research these devices are pretty inaccurate. They can be affected for example by someone moving next to you, or movement resulting from heavy snoring or apnea events. There is evidence in fact from a number of researchers that these monitors can do more harm than good. For example research at the Rush Medical Center in Chicago, reported in the Journal of Sleep Medicine, cautioned the use of sleep monitoring wearables for two reasons. First, despite their inherent inaccuracy, users believed their data above that of professional sleep monitors; even when they were experiencing good sleep, they would believe that they were not, if the wearable said so. Second, the suspect data actually caused anxiety which can make it more difficult to get a good night’s sleep rather than less. And the suspect data are used merely to make recommendations to improve sleep behavior such as don’t drink alcohol or coffee in the evening, keep the bedroom free of computers and smartphones, reduce the room temperature and wear ear-plugs – hardly earth-shattering insights. I don't know if this technology is available on smart watches or not, but the technology does exist. CPAP (continuous positive air pressure) machines—used to treat heavy snoring and sleep apnea—can record when the subject is sleeping and when they are not.  Of course, they make this determination by monitoring the person's breathing. It may or may not yet be possible to determine this by simply monitoring the pulse.

Smart watches has a sensor called Accelerometer and Gyroscope inbuilt within it, which can detect the motion of our body while we sleep. This process is called as actigraphy, in which the motion data output of sensors is converted into sleep patterns and hence the sleep time is estimated.

Most smartwatches have accelerometers. If you are not moving for a long time, just may be one movement in several minutes, they assume you are sleeping. If you take off smartwatch for several hours at night time, same assumption is made.

Many fitness wearables such as the Misfit Shine and the Jawbone Up do this quite well. I've compared the my Misfit's record to the information recorded by my prescription C-PAP and found it to be very accurate.

Smart watches use either galvanic sensors or optical sensors, to determine heart rate. It’s obvious to the smart watches software, that you are sleeping, because your heart rate slows down and becomes less erratic.

Your heart rate slows down and normalizes as well as you breathing does. But when you are awake it’s like all over the place because you are doing different things throughout the day. But when you are sleeping the heartbeat stays at one constant pace.
